results.title: Germany’s Far Right Is Nowhere in the Election. But It’s ‘Here to Stay.’
results.abstract: In the next national Parliament, the far-right Alternative for Germany party is likely to remain a pariah force. But it looks assured, too, of a role in shaping the country’s future.

multimedia.caption: Supporters of the far-right Alternative for Germany party, or AfD, at a rally last month. The party’s popularity has slipped since the last elections, but the AfD looks likely to stay in Parliament.

results.title: Australia’s Submarines Make Waves in Asia Long Before They Go to Sea
results.abstract: Some nations fear an accelerated arms buildup in a region where larger countries have already ramped up their military spending or capabilities.

results.title: Top Adviser to Ukrainian President Is Targeted in an Assassination Attempt
results.abstract: The adviser, Serhiy Shefir, was unharmed, but his driver was shot and wounded in an attack outside Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital.
results.byline: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Michael Schwirtz

results.abstract: The 5.9-magnitude quake damaged buildings in Melbourne, but there were no immediate reports of serious injuries or deaths.

results.title: China Pledges to Stop Building Coal-Burning Power Plants Abroad
results.abstract: It marks a major shift for one of the biggest backers of coal-fired plants globally. Still, China remains heavily reliant on new coal plants at home, and is the world’s top emitter of greenhouse gases.
results.byline: By Somini Sengupta and Rick Gladstone
des_facet: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

results.title: Taliban Complete Interim Government, Still Without Women
results.abstract: The Taliban spurned calls from the United Nations and big donors to include women in its new cabinet, but did add a few men from minority ethnic groups.

results.abstract: The president said he wants global cooperation to meet challenges, but some allies and adversaries say his actions point to confrontation with China and unilateral action, belying his words.

results.title: Trudeau Wins, but Is Diminished by a Futile Election
results.abstract: The prime minister struggled to find a campaign issue that could distinguish his party and expand its power in Parliament.

results.title: Pakistan Laments Cricket Matches Unplayed, and Blames Politics
results.abstract: Many see the pullouts by the England and New Zealand teams as punishment for the country’s support of the Afghan Taliban.

results.title: They Never Could Work From Home. These Are Their Stories.
results.abstract: A parallel universe of millions of employees did not have the luxury of thinking about returning to the office — they never left. Six workers share their experiences.

results.title: Pressure Grows on U.S. Companies to Share Covid Vaccine Technology
results.abstract: Moderna accepted $2.5 billion in taxpayer money to develop its Covid-19 vaccine. But officials in the U.S. and overseas are having trouble persuading the company to license its technology.
results.byline: By Stephanie Nolen and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

multimedia.caption: A man receiving a Moderna vaccine in Indonesia. Frustration is growing with Moderna, which is not sharing its technology so the poorest nations can produce the shot themselves.
A man receiving a Moderna vaccine in Indonesia. Frustration is growing with Moderna, which is not sharing its technology so the poorest nations can produce the shot themselves.

results.title: Moderna vs. Pfizer: Both Knockouts, but One Seems to Have the Edge
results.abstract: A series of studies found that the Moderna vaccine seemed to be more protective over the long term than the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine. Here’s why.

results.abstract: Hundreds of people were killed in Oppau in an explosion at a chemical plant. It ripped the roofs from houses and sent shock waves across neighboring towns.

results.abstract: Dr. Nkengasong will be the first person of African origin to oversee the U.S. government program combating H.I.V., which has ravaged the continent.

results.title: Sudan Leaders Say They Thwarted Coup Attempt by Loyalists of Former Dictator
results.abstract: Government officials blamed the bid on supporters of longtime ruler Omar Hassan al-Bashir, who was overthrown in 2019 by a military takeover prompted by widespread popular protests.

results.abstract: Many leaders are taking advantage of the in-person platform, but others sent recorded video or had lower-ranking officials step in. Either way, in several cases that choice signals a message, too.
